facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 132 of 1959 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No., 132 of 1959. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 23, 1956 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 291 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 23, 1956 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 291 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 23, 1956 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 291 of 1955. Veda Vyasa and C. P. Lal, for the appellant. P. Goyal, for the respondents. 1962. February 6.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on February 6, 1962 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. February 6. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the Allahabad High Court. The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these.

facts.text: The three respondents were students of G. S. Hindu Intermediate College at Sikandrarao.

anchor.surface_text: The three respondents were students of G. S. Hindu Intermediate College at Sikandrarao and appeared at the Intermediate  Commerce  Examination company- ducted by the appellant in the year 1954.

facts.text: The three respondents appeared at the Intermediate Commerce Examination conducted by the appellant in 1954.

anchor.surface_text: and appeared at the Intermediate  Commerce  Examination company- ducted by the appellant in the year 1954. On June 12, 1954, the result of the examination was published in newspapers and the three respondents passed in the second division.

facts.text: On June 12, 1954, the result of the examination was published in newspapers and the three respondents passed in the second division.

anchor.surface_text: On June 12, 1954, the result of the examination was published in newspapers and the three respondents passed in the second division. Thereafter they prosecuted further studies. But in December 1954, their fathers and guardians received information

facts.text: Thereafter the respondents prosecuted further studies.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter they prosecuted further studies. But in December 1954, their fathers and guardians received information from the Principal of the G. S. Hindu Intermediate College that the Examinations Committee of the appellant  hereinafter referred to as the Committee  had cancelled

facts.text: In December 1954, their fathers and guardians received information from the Principal that the Committee had cancelled the result of the respondents for the 1954 examination and debarred them from 1955 examination.

anchor.surface_text: But in December 1954, their fathers and guardians received information from the Principal of the G. S. Hindu Intermediate College that the Examinations Committee of the appellant  hereinafter referred to as the Committee  had cancelled the result of the respondents for the examination of 1954 and further that they had been debarred from appearing at the examination of 1955.

facts.text: The respondents filed a writ petition in the High Court contending no opportunity to rebut allegations, violation of natural justice, Act and Code.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondents filed a write petition in the High Court companytending that the Committee had never afforded any opportunity to them to rebut the allegations made against them and that they were never informed about the nature of the unfair means used by them in the said exa- mination and the first thing they companye to know was the resolution of the Committee canceling their results and debating them from appearing in the examination of 1955.

facts.text: The appellant's case was that the respondents had used unfair means at the examination, cases reported to Committee, thorough inquiry conducted.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant opposed the application and its case was that the respondents had used unfair means at the examination and their cases were reported to the Committee under the Regulations and the Committee had acted under the, powers companyferred on it under the Act and the Regulations framed thereunder after a thorough inquiry.

facts.text: No opportunity was afforded to the respondents to rebut the allegations in the inquiry by the Committee.

anchor.surface_text: It was number disputed, however, that numberopportunity had been afforded to the respondents to rebut the allegations against them in the inquiry made by the Committee which resulted in the resolution canceling the results of the examination.

facts.text: The learned Single Judge rejected the writ petition holding no duty to act judicially or give opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge held that numberduty was cast on the Committee to act judicially and there was numberstatutory obligation on the Committee to give an opportunity to every examine to be heard therefore he rejected the petition.

facts.text: Respondents appealed to Division Bench: Dayal and Brijmohan Lall, JJ., who differed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then went in appeal which was heared by Dayal and Brijmohan Lall, JJ., who however differed. Brijmohan Lall, J., was of opinion that the Committee was number required to act judicially or quasijudicially

facts.text: The matter was referred to third Judge Agarwala J., who held respondents entitled to hearing, appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The matter then camo before a third learned Judge, Agarwala, He was doubtful whether the view of the bench that there was numberduty cast on the Committee to act judicially in the present case was companyrect but as on that matter the two learned Judges were in agreement, he dealt with the case on the basis that the Committee was acting merely administratively, Even so, he came to the companyclusion that the respondents were entitled to a hearing

facts.text: Allahabad High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the Allahabad High Court. The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. The three respondents were students of G. S. Hindu Intermediate College at Sikandrarao

facts.text: Committee cancelled results and debarred respondents from 1955 exam under Rule 1(1) of Chap. VI of Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1  1  of Chap. VI with which we are particularly companycerned reads as follows-- It shall be the duty of the Examinations Committee subject to sanction and companytrol of the Board.  1  to companysider cases where examines have companycealed any fact or made a false statement ill their application forms

facts.text: No express provision in Act or Regulations requiring Committee to give hearing to examinees.

anchor.surface_text: Further, there is numberexpress provision in the Act or the Regulations casting a duty on the Committee to act judicially when exercising its powers under r. 1  1  and the question whether the Committee has to act judicially when exercising these powers will have to be decided

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Committee acts quasi-judicially under Rule 1(1) and must give hearing.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Committee when it exercises its powers under r. 1  1  is acting quasijudicially and the principles of natural justice which require that the other party,  namely, the examinee in this case  must be heard, will apply to the proceedings before the Committee.

facts.text: High Court allowed the writ petition on ground no opportunity given.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that though the view of the High Court that the Committee was acting merely administratively when proceeding under r. 1  1  is number companyrect, its final decision allowing the writ petition on the ground that numberopportunity was given to the respondents

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court's final decision allowing writ petition.

The procedure thus adopted by the appellant was said to be in violation of the principles of natural justice inasmuch as they were given numberopportunity whatsoever to defend themselves and to show cause against the action companytemplated against them. It was further companytended that the procedure adopted by the

appellant violated the provisions of the U. Intermediate Education Act, No. II of 1921  hereinafter referred to as the Act  and the U. P. Education Code, and therefore, the resolution canceling their results and debarring them from appearing in the later examination was without jurisdiction and illegal. They therefore prayed for a proper writ or order canceling the resolution of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1  1  of Chap. VI with which we are particularly companycerned reads as follows-- It shall be the duty of the Examinations Committee subject to sanction and companytrol of the Board.  1  to companysider cases where examines have companycealed any fact or made a false statement ill their application forms or a breach of rules and regulations to secure undue admis- sion to an examination or used unfair means or companymitted fraud  including impersonation  at the examination or are guilty or a moral offence or indiscipline and to award penalty which may be one or more of the following -- 1  withdrawal of certificate of having passed the examination  2  cancellation of the examination  3  exclusion from the examination.

anchor.surface_text: The principles, as I apprehend them are that if a statute empowers an authority, number being a companyrt in the ordinary sense, to decide disputes arising out of a claim made by one party under the statute which claim is opposed by another party and to determine the respective rights of the companytesting parties who are opposed to each other, there is a vis and prima farcie and in the absence of any thing in the statute to the companytrary it is the duty of the authority to act judicially and the decision of the authority is a quasi- judicial act and that if a statutory authority has power to do any act which will prejudicially affect the subject, then, although there are number two parties apart from the authority and the companytest is between the authority proposing to do the act and the subject opposing it, the final determination of the authority Will yet be a quasi. judicial act provided the authority is required by the statute to act judicially.  1  1950 S.C.R, 621, 725. In other words, while the presence of two parties besides the deciding authority will prima facie and in the absence of any other factor impose upon the authority the duty to act judicially, the absence of two such parties is number decisive in taking the act of the authority out of the category of quasi- judicial act if the authority is nevertheless required by the statute to act judicially.

issues.text: whether the respondents were entitled to a hearing before the appellant decided to cancel the results

anchor.surface_text: A large number of companytentions appear to have been urged in the High Court but we are here only companycerned with one of them, namely, whether the respondents were entitled to a hearing before the appellant decided to cancel the results.

issues.text: whether any duty is cast on the Committee under the Act and Regulations to act judicially and therefore it is a quasi-judicial body

anchor.surface_text: The first question therefore which falls for company sideration is whether any duty is cast on the Committee under the Act and Regulations to act judicially and therefore it is a quasi-judicial body. What companystitutes ,a quasi-judicial act was discussed in the Province or Bombay v. Kusaldas S. Advani.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually they referred three questions to be answered by another learned Judge and one of these questions was whether the failure of the Committee to provide an opportunity to the respondents of being heard vitiated its order, which was of an administrative nature.

It is companytended that where a body is acting merely administratively, it is number necessary that it should give a hearing to a party who might be affected by its decision and that the principles of natural justice, including the maxim, audi alteram partem, apply only to judicial or quasi-judicial bodies,

arguments.claim: The procedure adopted by the appellant violated the principles of natural justice as no opportunity was given to rebut allegations or show cause

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondents filed a write petition in the High Court contending that the Committee had never afforded any opportunity to them to rebut the allegations made against them and that they were never informed about the nature of the unfair means used by them in the said exa- mination and the first thing they came to know was the resolution of the Committee canceling their results and debarred them from appearing in the examination of 1955. The procedure thus adopted by the appellant was said to be in violation of the principles of natural justice inasmuch as they were given no opportunity whatsoever to defend themselves and to show cause against the action contemplated against them.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Committee is proceeding should also be heard. The effect of the decision of the Committee may in an extreme case blast the career of a young student f

arguments.court_reasoning: Committee acts quasi-judicially requiring hearing under natural justice

arguments.claim: The procedure violated the U.P. Intermediate Education Act and U.P. Education Code, making the resolution without jurisdiction and illegal

anchor.surface_text: The procedure thus adopted by the appellant was said to be in violation of the principles of natural justice inasmuch as they were given no opportunity whatsoever to defend themselves and to show cause against the action contemplated against them. It was further contended that the procedure adopted by the appellant violated the provisions of the U. Intermediate Education Act, No. II of 1921 (hereinafter referred to as the Act) and the U. P. Education Code, and therefore, the resolution canceling their results and debarring them from appearing in the later examination was without jurisdiction and illegal.

arguments.claim: Respondents used unfair means, cases reported to Committee which acted under powers conferred by Act and Regulations after thorough inquiry

anchor.surface_text: The appellant opposed the application and its case was that the respondents had used unfair means at the examination and their cases were reported to the Committee under the Regulations and the Committee had acted under the powers conferred on it under the Act and the Regulations framed thereunder after a thorough inquiry. It was not disputed, however, that no opportunity had been afforded to the respondents to rebut the allegations against them in the inquiry made by the Committee which resulted in the resolution canceling the results of the examination.

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepts power under rule but requires hearing

arguments.claim: No duty cast on Committee to act judicially or give statutory opportunity to examinees

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the respondents before the learned Single Judge was that the appellant was under a duty to act judicially and therefore the respondents should have been given a hearing before any order was passed against them. The learned Single Judge held that no duty was cast on the Committee to act judicially and there was no statutory obligation on the Committee to give an opportunity to every examinee to be heard therefore he rejected the petition.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ere is numberexpress provision in the Act or the Regulations casting a duty on the Committee to act judicially when exercising its powers under r. 1

arguments.court_reasoning: Committee required to act judicially inferred from rule and circumstances

arguments.claim: Committee not required to act judicially/quasi-judicially but rule of natural justice (audi alteram partem) applies even administratively

anchor.surface_text: Brijmohan Lall, J., was of opinion that the Committee was not required to act judicially or quasijudicially when it considered cases of this kind and was acting merely administratively but nevertheless was of the opinion that one of the rules of natural justice contained in the maxim audi alteram partem would apply in this case, even though the Committee was acting administratively. He was therefore in favour of allowing the appeal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Committee is proceeding should also be heard. The effect of the decision of the Committee may in an extreme case blast the career of a young student f

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees hearing required but holds quasi-judicial not merely administrative

arguments.claim: Committee acting merely administratively, not bound to give hearing as audi alteram partem applies only to judicial/quasi-judicial

anchor.surface_text: Dayal J., agreed with the view of Brijmohan Lall, J., that in the present case no duty was cast on the Committee to act judicially and that the action of the Committee was merely administrative. He however did not agree that the Committee acted in violation of the principles of natural justice inasmuch as it did not give a hearing to the respondents. He was of the view that as the Committee was acting merely administratively it was not bound to give a hearing, as the maxim audi alteram partem applied only to judicial or quasijudicial tribunals.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ere is numberexpress provision in the Act or the Regulations casting a duty on the Committee to act judicially when exercising its powers under r. 1

arguments.claim: Respondents entitled to hearing even if Committee acting merely administratively

anchor.surface_text: The matter then came before a third learned Judge, Agarwala, He was doubtful whether the view of the bench that there was no duty cast on the Committee to act judicially in the present case was correct but as on that matter the two learned Judges were in agreement, he dealt with the case on the basis that the Committee was acting merely administratively, Even so, he came to the conclusion that the respondents were entitled to a hearing

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Committee is proceeding should also be heard. The effect of the decision of the Committee may in an extreme case blast the career of a young student f

arguments.claim: High Court wrong; where body acts merely administratively no necessity to give hearing; natural justice applies only to judicial/quasi-judicial bodies

anchor.surface_text: The main contention on behalf of the appellant is that the High Court was wrong in the view it took that an opportunity for hearing was necessary in this case even though the Committee acted merely administratively. It is contended that where a body is acting merely administratively, it is not necessary that it should give a hearing to a party who might be affected by its decision and that the principles of natural justice, including the maxim, audi alteram partem, apply only to judicial or quasi-judicial bodies, i.e., bodies on whom a duty is cast to act judicially.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: out of a claim made by one party under the statute which claim is opposed by another party and to determine the respective rights of the companytestin

arguments.court_reasoning: Duty to act judicially inferred despite no express provision

arguments.claim: High Court final decision correct but erred in holding administrative; duty to act judicially considering circumstances, hence hearing required

anchor.surface_text: The respondents on the other hand contend that though the final decision of the High Court is correct, the High Court was not right in holding that the Committee was acting merely administratively in a matter of this kind they contend that considering the entire circumstances which operate in cases of this kind, the High Court should have held that there was a duty to act judicially and therefore it was necessary to give an opportunity to the respondents to be heard before action was taken against them.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nd that if a statutory authority has power to do any act which will prejudicially affect the subject, then, although there are number two parties apar

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees duty judicial and hearing required

arguments.claim: Committee has duty to act judicially as quasi-judicial body per test in Province of Bombay v. Kusal Das: decides facts prejudicially affecting rights based on materials

anchor.surface_text: The principles, as I apprehend them are that if a statute empowers an authority, not being a court in the ordinary sense, to decide disputes arising out of a claim made by one party under the statute which claim is opposed by another party and to determine the respective rights of the contesting parties who are opposed to each other, there is a lis and prima facie and in the absence of anything in the statute to the contrary it is the duty of the authority to act judicially and the decision of the authority is a quasi- judicial act...

arguments.claim: Under Rule 1(1) Chap VI, Committee must objectively determine facts (unfair means etc.) from materials before penalizing, implying quasi-judicial duty to hear

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1 (1) of Chap. VI with which we are particularly concerned reads as follows-- It shall be the duty of the Examinations Committee subject to sanction and control of the Board (1) to consider cases where examinees have concealed any fact or made a false statement in their application forms or a breach of rules and regulations to secure undue admission to an examination or used unfair means... Before the Committee decides to award any penalty it has to come to an objective determination on certain facts...

arguments.claim: Serious consequences (stigma, career damage, prosecution) and nature of misconduct require Committee to act judicially

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the decision of the Committee may in an extreme case blast the career of a young student for life and in any case will put a serious stigma on the examinee concerned which may damage him in later life. The nature of misconduct which the Committee has to find under r. 1 (1) in some cases is of a serious nature, for example, impersonation, commission of fraud...

arguments.claim: View supported by Calcutta High Court precedents (Dipa Pal, B.C. Das Gupta)

anchor.surface_text: This view was taken by the Calcutta High Court in Dipa Pal v. University of Calcutta and B. C. Das Gupta v. Bijoyranjan Rakshit, in similar circumstances and is in our opinion correct.

arguments.claim: Large number of cases before Committee makes it impossible to act judicially/hear if required

anchor.surface_text: It is urged on behalf of the appellant that there are a large number of cases which come up before the Committee under r. 1 (1), and if the Committee is held to act judicially as a quasijudicial tribunal in the matter it will find it impossible to carry on its task.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in the Act or the Regulations casting a duty on the Committee to act judicially, the manner of the disposal, based as it must be on materials placed b

arguments.court_reasoning: Not a criterion; procedure can be prescribed

holdings.text: the mere fact that the Act or the Regulations do not make it obligatory on the Committee to call for an explanation and to hear the examinee is not conclusive on the question whether the Committee acts as a quasi-judicial body in exercising its powers under r. 1(1)

anchor.surface_text: Further, there is no express provision in the Act or the Regulations casting a duty on the Committee to act judicially when exercising its powers under r. 1(1) and the question whether the Committee has to act judicially when exercising these powers will have to be decided

holdings.reasoning_summary: Silence in statute does not preclude duty to act judicially when inferred from function, materials needed, and consequences

holdings.text: Before the Committee decides to award any penalty it has to come to an objective determination on certain facts and only when it comes to the conclusion that those facts are established that it can proceed to punish the examinee concerned

anchor.surface_text: Before the Committee decides to award any penalty it has to come to an objective determination on certain facts and only when it comes to the conclusion that those facts are established that it can proceed to punish the examinee concerned. The facts which the Committee has to find before it takes action are whether the examinee has concealed any fact or made a false statement

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 1(1) requires finding specific facts like unfair means based on materials placed before it

holdings.text: the Committee must be held to act judicially [...] a duty is cast on the Committee to act judicially in this matter particularly as it has to decide objectively certain facts which may seriously affect the rights and careers of examinees

anchor.surface_text: Considering therefore the serious consequences following the decision of the Committee and the serious nature of the misconduct which may be found in some cases under r. 1(1), it seems to us that the Committee must be held to act judicially in circumstances as these.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Serious stigma and career impact, nature of misconduct, objective fact-finding based on materials imply judicial duty per Advani test

holdings.text: the Committee when it exercises its powers under r. 1(1) is acting quasi-judicially and the principles of natural justice which require that the other party, namely, the examinee in this case must be heard, will apply to the proceedings before the Committee

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Committee when it exercises its powers under r. 1  1  is acting quasijudicially and the principles of natural justice which require that the other party,  namely, the examinee in this case  must be heard, will apply to the proceedings before the Committee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial function necessitates audi alteram partem under natural justice

holdings.text: This in our opinion is not a criterion for deciding whether a duty is cast to act judicially in view of all the circumstances of the case

anchor.surface_text: It is urged on behalf of the appellant that there are a large number of cases which come up before the Committee under r. 1(1), and if the Committee is held to act judicially as a quasijudicial tribunal in the matter it will find it impossible to carry on its task. This in our opinion is not criterion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Volume of cases does not negate judicial duty; procedure can be regulated by rules

holdings.text: though the view of the High Court that the Committee was acting merely administratively when proceeding under r. 1(1) is not correct, its final decision allowing the writ petition on the ground that no opportunity was given to the respondents to put forward their cases before the Committee is correct

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that though the view of the High Court that the Committee was acting merely administratively when proceeding under r. 1  1  is number correct, its final decision allowing the writ petition on the ground that numberopportunity was given to the respondents

holdings.reasoning_summary: No hearing provided vitiates order as violates natural justice in quasi-judicial proceeding

precedents.citation: Province or Bombay v. Kusaldas S. Advani.  1

anchor.surface_text: What companystitutes ,a quasi-judicial act was discussed in the Province or Bombay v. Kusaldas S. Advani.  1  The principle, have been summarised by Das, J.  as he was then , at p. 725 in these words- The principles, as I apprehend them are that if a statute empowers an authority, number being a companyrt in the ordinary sense, to decide disputes arising out of a claim made by one party under the statute which claim is opposed by another party and to determine the respective rights of the companytesting parties who are opposed to each other, there is a vis and prima farcie and in the absence of any thing in the statute to the companytrary it is the duty of the authority to act judicially and the decision of the authority is a quasi- judicial act and that if a statutory authority has power to do any act which will prejudicially affect the subject, then, although there are number two parties apart from the authority and the companytest is between the authority proposing to do the act and the subject opposing it, the final determination of the authority Will yet be a quasi. judicial act provided the authority is required by the statute to act judicially.

precedents.case_name: Province of Bombay v. Kusaldas S. Advani
precedents.cited_proposition: principles constituting a quasi-judicial act and duty to act judicially
precedents.cited_holding: The principles, as I apprehend them are that if a statute empowers an authority... provided the authority is required by the statute to act judicially.

precedents.citation: Nagendra Nath Bora v. The Commissioner of Hills Division Appeals, Assam 1

anchor.surface_text: These principles have been acted upon by this Court in latter cases see Nagendra Nath Bora v. The Commissioner of Hills Division Appeals, Assam 1 , Shri Radheshyam Khare v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 2 , Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation  , and Shivaji Nathubhai v. The Union of India 4 . Now it may be mentioned that the statute is number likely to provide in so many words that the authority passing the order is required to act judicially that can only be inferred from the express provisions of the statute in the first instance in each case and numberone circumstance alone will be determinative of the question whether the authority set up by the statute has the duty to act judicially or number.

precedents.case_name: Nagendra Nath Bora v. Commissioner of Hills Division Appeals, Assam

anchor.surface_text: These principles have been acted upon by this Court in latter cases see Nagendra Nath Bora v. The Commissioner of Hills Division Appeals, Assam 1 , Shri Radheshyam Khare v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 2 , Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation  , and Shivaji Nathubhai v. The Union of India 4 . Now it may be mentioned that the statute is number likely to provide in so many words that the authority passing the order is required to act judicially that can only be inferred from the express provisions of the statute in the first instance in each case and numberone circumstance alone will be determinative of the question whether the authority set up by the statute has the duty to act judicially or number.

precedents.cited_proposition: principles of quasi-judicial acts acted upon by this Court

anchor.surface_text: Shri Radheshyam Khare v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 2 , Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation  , and Shivaji Nathubhai v. The Union of India 4 . Now it may be mentioned that the statute is number likely to provide in so many words that the authority passing the order is required to act judicially that can only be inferred from the express provisions of the statute in the first instance in each case and numberone circumstance alone will be determinative of the question whether the authority set up by the statute has the duty to act judicially or number. The inference whether the authority acting under a statute where it is silent has the duty to act. judicially will depend, on the express provisions of the statute read along with the nature of the rights affected, the manner of the disposal provided the objective criterion if any to be adopted, the effect of the decision on the person affected and other indicia afforded by the statute.

precedents.case_name: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation
precedents.cited_proposition: principles of quasi-judicial acts acted upon by this Court

precedents.citation: Shivaji Nathubhai v. The Union of India 4

anchor.surface_text: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation  , and Shivaji Nathubhai v. The Union of India 4 . Now it may be mentioned that the statute is number likely to provide in so many words that the authority passing the order is required to act judicially that can only be inferred from the express provisions of the statute in the first instance in each case and numberone circumstance alone will be determinative of the question whether the authority set up by the statute has the duty to act judicially or number. The inference whether the authority acting under a statute where it is silent has the duty to act. judicially will depend, on the express provisions of the statute read along with the nature of the rights affected, the manner of the disposal provided the objective criterion if any to be adopted, the effect of the decision on the person affected and other indicia afforded by the statute. A duty to act judicially may arise in widely different circumstances which it will be impossible and indeed inadvisable to attempt to define exhaustively vide observations of Parker, J. in R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee  5 .

precedents.case_name: Shivaji Nathubhai v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: principles of quasi-judicial acts acted upon by this Court

precedents.citation: R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee  5

anchor.surface_text: A duty to act judicially may arise in widely different circumstances which it will be impossible and indeed inadvisable to attempt to define exhaustively vide observations of Parker, J. in R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee  5 .  1  1958 S.C.R. 1240.  2  1959 S.C.R. 1440.  3  1959 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 319.  4  1960 2 S.C.R. 775.  5  1952 2 Q.B. 413, We must therefore proceed to examine the pro. visions of the Act and the Regulations framed thereunder in companynection with matters of this kind to determine whether the Committee can be said to have the duty to act judicially when it deals with cases of examines using unfair means in examination halls.

precedents.case_name: R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee
precedents.cited_proposition: observations on circumstances giving rise to duty to act judicially

precedents.citation: Dipa Pul v. University of Calcutta,  1

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Committee when it exercises its powers under r. 1  1  is acting quasijudicially and the principles of natural justice which require that the other party,  namely, the examinee in this case  must be heard, will apply to the proceedings before the Committee. This view was taken by the Calcutta High Court in Dipa Pul v. University of Calcutta,  1  and B. C. Das Gupta v. Bijoyranjan Rakshit, in similar circumstances and is in our opinion companyrect.

precedents.case_name: Dipa Pul v. University of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: Committee acts quasi-judicially and must give hearing in unfair means cases

precedents.citation: B. C. Das Gupta v. Bijoyranjan Rakshit,

anchor.surface_text: This view was taken by the Calcutta High Court in Dipa Pul v. University of Calcutta,  1  and B. C. Das Gupta v. Bijoyranjan Rakshit, in similar circumstances and is in our opinion companyrect. It is urged on behalf of the appellant that there are a large number of cases which companye up before the Committee under r. 1  1 , and if the Committee is hold to act judicially as a quasijudicial tribunal in the matter it will find it impossible to carry on its task.

precedents.case_name: B. C. Das Gupta v. Bijoyranjan Rakshit
precedents.cited_proposition: Committee acts quasi-judicially and must give hearing in unfair means cases

anchor.surface_text: As was pointed out in Local Government Board v. Alridge,  1  all that is required is that the other party shall have an opportunity of adequately presenting his case. But what the procedure should be in detail will depend on the nature of the tribunal. There is numberdoubt that many of the powers of the Committee under Chap. VI are of administrative nature but where quasi- judicial duties are entrusted to administrative body like this it becomes a quasi-judicial body for performing these duties and it can prescribe its own procedure so long as the principles of natural justice are followed and adequate opportunity of presenting his case is given to the examinee.

precedents.cited_proposition: requirements of opportunity to present case in quasi-judicial proceedings
precedents.cited_holding: all that is required is that the other party shall have an opportunity of adequately presenting his case
